The second test case's array is "1100111", it will be divided into "11", "00" and "111", and their lengths are $$$2$$$, $$$4$$$, $$$8$$$. 

The minimum number of operations to make $$$s$$$ good is the following: 

Description: We have an array $$$ of length $$$n$$$. Initially, each element is equal to $$$0$$$. There is a pointer located on the first element. We can do the following two kinds of operations any number of times (possibly zero) in any order.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: The first kind of operations involves moving a pointer left (if the pointer is not on the first element, increase the element the pointer is currently on by 1. Then move it to the previous element.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: The second kind of operations involves moving a pointer right (if the pointer is not on the last element, increase the element the pointer is currently on by 1. Then move it to the next element. The pointer must end at the first element. The problem is to determine whether it's possible to obtain the array after some operations or not.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Input Specification: The first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ $$$(1\le t\le 1000)$$$  — the number of test cases. The description of the test cases follows.
children.label: empty

children.text:
The first line contains a single integer $$$n$$$ $$$(1\le n\le 2 \cdot 10^5)$$$  — the size of array $$$a$$$. 

The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$$$ $$-10^9 \le a_i \le 10^9$$$  — elements of the array.
children.label: empty

children.text: Output Specification: For each test case, print "Yes" (without quotes) if it's possible to obtain the array after some operations, and "No" (without quotes) otherwise.
children.label: empty

children.text: Notes: NoteIn the first test case we can be obtain the array after some operations, but the pointer won't be on the first element. The problem is to determine whether it's possible to obtain the array after some operations or not.
